#Text=III .
#Text=SNANA’S FAWN
#Text=The Little

#Text=Missouri was in her spring fullness , and the hills among which she found her way to the Great Muddy were profusely adorned with colors , much like those worn by the wild red man upon a holiday ! Looking toward the sunrise , one saw mysterious , deep shadows and bright prominences , while on the opposite side there was really an extravagant array of variegated hues .

#Text=Between the gorgeous buttes and rainbow-tinted ridges there were narrow plains , broken here and there by dry creeks or gulches , and these again were clothed scantily with poplars and sad-colored bull-berry bushes , while the bare spots were purple with the wild Dakota crocuses .

#Text=Upon the lowest of a series of natural terraces there stood on this May morning a young Sioux girl , whose graceful movements were not unlike those of a doe which chanced to be lurking in a neighboring gulch .

#Text=On the upper plains , not far away , were her young companions , all busily employed with the wewoptay , as it was called -- the sharp-pointed stick with which the Sioux women dig wild turnips .
#Text=They were gayly gossiping together , or each humming a love-song as she worked , only Snana stood somewhat apart from the rest ; in fact , concealed by the crest of the ridge .
#Text=She had paused in her digging and stood facing the sun-kissed buttes .

#Text=Above them in the clear blue sky the father sun was traveling upward as in haste , while to her receptive spirit there appealed an awful , unknown force , the silent speech of the Great Mystery , to which it seemed to her the whole world must be listening !
#Text=“ O Great Mystery ! the father of earthly things is coming to quicken us into life .
#Text=Have pity on me , I pray thee !
#Text=May
#Text=I some day become the mother of a great and brave race of warriors ! ”
#Text=So the maiden prayed silently .
#Text=It was now full-born day .
#Text=The sun shone hot upon the bare ground , and the drops stood upon Snana ’s forehead as she plied her long pole .
#Text=There was a cool spring in the dry creek bed near by , well hidden by a clump of chokecherry bushes , and she turned thither to cool her thirsty throat .
#Text=In the depths of the ravine her eye caught a familiar footprint -- the track of a doe with the young fawn beside it .
#Text=The hunting instinct arose within .
#Text=“ It will be a great feat if I can find and take from her the babe .
#Text=The little tawny skin shall be beautifully dressed by my mother .
#Text=The legs and the nose shall be embossed with porcupine quills .
#Text=It will be my work-bag , ” she said to herself .
#Text=As she stole forward on the fresh trail she scanned every nook , every clump of bushes .
#Text=There was a sudden rustle from within a grove of wild plum trees , thickly festooned with grape and clematis , and the doe mother bounded away as carelessly as if she were never to return .
#Text=Ah , a mother ’s ruse !
#Text=Snana entered the thorny enclosure , which was almost a rude teepee , and , tucked away in the furthermost corner , lay something with a trout-like , speckled , tawny coat .
#Text=She bent over it .
#Text=The fawn was apparently sleeping .
#Text=Presently its eyes moved a bit , and a shiver passed through its subtle body .
#Text=“ Thou shalt not die ; thy skin shall not become my work-bag ! ” unconsciously the maiden spoke .
#Text=The mother sympathy had taken hold on her mind .
#Text=She picked the fawn up tenderly , bound its legs , and put it on her back to carry like an Indian babe in the folds of her robe .
#Text=“ I cannot leave you alone , Tachinchala .
#Text=Your mother is not here .
#Text=Our hunters will soon return by this road , and your mother has left behind her two plain tracks leading to this thicket , ” she murmured .
#Text=The wild creature struggled vigorously for a minute , and then became quiet .
#Text=Its graceful head protruded from the elkskin robe just over Snana ’s shoulder .
#Text=She was slowly climbing the slope with her burden , when suddenly like an apparition the doe-mother stood before her .
#Text=The fawn called loudly when it was first seized , and the mother was not too far away to hear .
#Text=Now she called frantically for her child , at the same time stamping with her delicate fore-feet .
#Text=“ Yes , sister , you are right ; she is yours ; but you cannot save her to-day !
#Text=The hunters will soon be here .
#Text=Let me keep her for you ; I will return her to you safely .
#Text=And hear me , O sister of the woods , that some day I may become the mother of a noble race of warriors and of fine women , as handsome as you are ! ”
#Text=At this moment the quick eyes of the Indian girl detected something strange in the doe ’s actions .
#Text=She glanced in every direction and behold ! a grizzly bear was cautiously approaching the group from a considerable distance .
#Text=“ Run , run , sister ! I shall save your child if I can , ” she cried , and flew for the nearest scrub oak on the edge of the bank .
#Text=Up the tree she scrambled , with the fawn still securely bound to her back .

#Text=The grizzly came on with teeth exposed , and the doe-mother in her flight came between him and the tree , giving a series of indignant snorts as she ran , and so distracted Mato from his object of attack ; but only for a few seconds -- then on he came !
